sections.heading: Employment Distribution and Sector Dominance in Pacific Island Countries and Vanuatu
charts_title: Employment Numbers Across Pacific Island Countries
Sex and Sector Employment in Vanuatu
sections.insight: Solomon Islands leads employment numbers, while Vanuatu shows male-dominant, agriculture-centered workforce.

sections.heading: Male Dominance in Employment Across Pacific Island Countries and Economic Sectors
charts_title: Employed Persons by Sex in Pacific Island Countries
Employment by Sex Across Economic Sectors
sections.insight: Males consistently outnumber females in employment, especially in agriculture and construction sectors.

sections.heading: Gender and Sector Employment Patterns in Solomon Islands and Vanuatu
charts_title: Employment by Sex and Sector in Solomon Islands
Employment by Sex and Sector in Vanuatu
sections.insight: Both countries have male-dominated employment overall, with sectoral gender imbalances in agriculture and services.

conclusion.content: Employment is heavily concentrated in Solomon Islands (95,024) and Vanuatu (65,779). Agriculture, Fishing, and Wholesale dominate employment, with males leading in key sectors. This suggests economic size and traditional sectors shape workforce distribution in the Pacific.

Male employment consistently surpasses female across Pacific Islands, often at 60% vs 40%. Sectoral divides are stark, with men dominating agriculture and construction, while women prevail in social work and accommodation. These imbalances reveal enduring gender roles affecting labor market equity.

In Solomon Islands and Vanuatu, males dominate agriculture employment, while females lead in sectors like accommodation. Both countries show strong gender segregation, especially in construction and wholesale. These patterns emphasize persistent cultural norms influencing sectoral and gender employment.

poster_Q: How Do Gender Roles and Economic Sectors Shape Employment in Pacific Islands?
